title: How to Preserve Avocados

steps.headline: Leave the pit in the half you are refrigerating.
steps.description: If you only need half an avocado for your recipe, meal, or snack, you can refrigerate the other half. Leave the pit in the unused half, as this will help preserve the avocado.

steps.headline: Put half an avocado and a piece of cut-up onion in an airtight container.
steps.description: Cut a large piece of onion and put it in an airtight container. Then, place the avocado half, with the pit still in it, in the container. Seal the container. The onion's taste and smell won't transfer to your avocado, so don't worry about that!

steps.headline: Keep the container in your fridge for up to 5 days.
steps.description: Place the container in the fridge for up to 5 days before using the avocado. Storing your avocado with a piece of onion preserves it better than storing the avocado by itself.

steps.headline: Stock up on avocados.
steps.description: In some areas, avocados can be incredibly expensive. Buy a ton of them when they're in season and on sale at your local market. You can stock up on enough to last you several months since you'll be preserving them in the freezer.

steps.headline: Pit and peel the avocados.
steps.description: Cut your avocados in half and use the blade of a knife to remove the pit. Peel off the skin of the avocados, then place the flesh in a large mixing bowl. Discard the skin and pits, or use a pit to grow your own avocado tree. Practice safe knife skills in the kitchen to prevent injuries.

steps.headline: Mash the avocados with lemon juice.
steps.description: Add 1 Tbsp (14.8 mL) of lemon juice per avocado to the mixing bowl. Use fresh, rather than store-bought, lemon juice, or opt for fresh lime juice. The acid in the juice helps keep your avocados fresh and tasty. After adding the lemon juice, mash the avocados using a kitchen mixer or potato masher.

steps.headline: Put the mashed avocados in an airtight container.
steps.description: Use a spatula to transfer the mashed avocados from the bowl to a quart-sized plastic Ziploc freezer bag. Squeeze out all the air before you seal the bag. Alternatively, you can put the mashed avocados in an ice cube tray and wrap it with plastic wrap if you'd like smaller portions.

steps.headline: Freeze them for up to 5 months.
steps.description: Store your avocados in the freezer either in the bag or in the plastic-wrapped ice cube tray. Use them up in 4 to 5 months for the best flavor.

steps.headline: Use the avocado within 24 hours of thawing.
steps.description: Take out a whole bag of mashed avocado and allow it to defrost in your refrigerator overnight. Or, you can break or cut off a smaller portion while the avocado is still frozen and let it thaw on your countertop. Just be sure to use the thawed avocado within 24 hours or it will start to turn brown.

steps.headline: Combine water, vinegar, honey and salt in a medium saucepan.
steps.description: Put ⅔ cup (158 mL) of water, ½ cup (118 mL) of white balsamic vinegar, 1 Tbsp (14.8 mL) of honey, and ½ Tbsp (7.5 g) of salt in a medium saucepan. Stir the mixture to combine the ingredients, and place the saucepan on a stovetop burner.

steps.headline: Bring the brine mixture to a boil, then remove it from heat.
steps.description: Heat the brine mixture over medium heat while stirring to dissolve the salt and combine the ingredients. Once the mixture comes to a boil, remove it from heat and let it cool completely. Don't forget to turn off your burner.

steps.headline: Put garlic, crushed red pepper, and peppercorns in a jar.
steps.description: Peel and thinly slice 4 cloves of garlic. Put the garlic, 1 ½ tsp (7.5 g) of crushed red pepper, and 1 ½ tsp (7.5 g) of peppercorns in a pint-sized jar with a tight-fitting lid.

steps.headline: Prepare an avocado.
steps.description: Cut one avocado lengthwise in half. Remove the pit and peel off the skin, keeping the halves intact. Cut the avocado widthwise into ½-in (1.27-cm) pieces. Be sure you are using safe knife skills in the kitchen to prevent injuries.

steps.headline: Add the brine, avocado, rosemary, and lemon to the jar.
steps.description: Put the avocado pieces in the jar with the garlic, red pepper, and peppercorns. Pour the cooled brine over the avocados into the jar. Add 1 thin slice of fresh lemon, cut in half, and one 2-in (5.1-cm) sprig of rosemary.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the jar for at least 6 hours.
steps.description: Cover the jar with a tight-fitting lid. Place it in your refrigerator for at least 6 hours before serving to give the avocado time to absorb the other ingredients.

steps.headline: Remove the avocados from the brine to serve.
steps.description: When you're ready to serve your pickled avocados, remove them from the brine. Use your pickled avocados on sandwiches, as hors d'oeurvres, in salads, or as a snack!

text: Refrigerating Partial Avocados Leave the pit in the half you are refrigerating. If you only need half an avocado for your recipe, meal, or snack, you can refrigerate the other half. Leave the pit in the unused half, as this will help preserve the avocado. Put half an avocado and a piece of cut-up onion in an airtight container. Cut a large piece of onion and put it in an airtight container. Then, place the avocado half, with the pit still in it, in the container. Seal the container. The onion's taste and smell won't transfer to your avocado, so don't worry about that! Keep the container in your fridge for up to 5 days. Place the container in the fridge for up to 5 days before using the avocado. Storing your avocado with a piece of onion preserves it better than storing the avocado by itself. Freezing Mashed Avocados Stock up on avocados. In some areas, avocados can be incredibly expensive. Buy a ton of them when they're in season and on sale at your local market. You can stock up on enough to last you several months since you'll be preserving them in the freezer. Pit and peel the avocados. Cut your avocados in half and use the blade of a knife to remove the pit. Peel off the skin of the avocados, then place the flesh in a large mixing bowl. Discard the skin and pits, or use a pit to grow your own avocado tree. Practice safe knife skills in the kitchen to prevent injuries. Mash the avocados with lemon juice. Add 1 Tbsp (14.8 mL) of lemon juice per avocado to the mixing bowl. Use fresh, rather than store-bought, lemon juice, or opt for fresh lime juice. The acid in the juice helps keep your avocados fresh and tasty. After adding the lemon juice, mash the avocados using a kitchen mixer or potato masher. Put the mashed avocados in an airtight container. Use a spatula to transfer the mashed avocados from the bowl to a quart-sized plastic Ziploc freezer bag. Squeeze out all the air before you seal the bag. Alternatively, you can put the mashed avocados in an ice cube tray and wrap it with plastic wrap if you'd like smaller portions. Freeze them for up to 5 months. Store your avocados in the freezer either in the bag or in the plastic-wrapped ice cube tray. Use them up in 4 to 5 months for the best flavor. Use the avocado within 24 hours of thawing. Take out a whole bag of mashed avocado and allow it to defrost in your refrigerator overnight. Or, you can break or cut off a smaller portion while the avocado is still frozen and let it thaw on your countertop. Just be sure to use the thawed avocado within 24 hours or it will start to turn brown. Pickling Avocados Combine water, vinegar, honey and salt in a medium saucepan. Put ⅔ cup (158 mL) of water, ½ cup (118 mL) of white balsamic vinegar, 1 Tbsp (14.8 mL) of honey, and ½ Tbsp (7.5 g) of salt in a medium saucepan. Stir the mixture to combine the ingredients, and place the saucepan on a stovetop burner. Bring the brine mixture to a boil, then remove it from heat. Heat the brine mixture over medium heat while stirring to dissolve the salt and combine the ingredients. Once the mixture comes to a boil, remove it from heat and let it cool completely. Don't forget to turn off your burner. Put garlic, crushed red pepper, and peppercorns in a jar. Peel and thinly slice 4 cloves of garlic. Put the garlic, 1 ½ tsp (7.5 g) of crushed red pepper, and 1 ½ tsp (7.5 g) of peppercorns in a pint-sized jar with a tight-fitting lid. Prepare an avocado. Cut one avocado lengthwise in half. Remove the pit and peel off the skin, keeping the halves intact. Cut the avocado widthwise into ½-in (1.27-cm) pieces. Be sure you are using safe knife skills in the kitchen to prevent injuries. Add the brine, avocado, rosemary, and lemon to the jar. Put the avocado pieces in the jar with the garlic, red pepper, and peppercorns. Pour the cooled brine over the avocados into the jar. Add 1 thin slice of fresh lemon, cut in half, and one 2-in (5.1-cm) sprig of rosemary. Refrigerate the jar for at least 6 hours. Cover the jar with a tight-fitting lid. Place it in your refrigerator for at least 6 hours before serving to give the avocado time to absorb the other ingredients. Remove the avocados from the brine to serve. When you're ready to serve your pickled avocados, remove them from the brine. Use your pickled avocados on sandwiches, as hors d'oeurvres, in salads, or as a snack!
